title: 112_s1502
content: The Act is titled the "Clean Rivers Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Clean Rivers Act of 2011" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "gathering lines," "hazardous liquid pipeline facility," and "Indian tribe." The "Clean Rivers Act of 2011" defines the term "Indian tribe" according to the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 3. REVIEW OF PIPELINE RIVER CROSSINGS. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration must review regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water with a width of at least 100 feet within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The review includes data on river geomorphology, flood hydraulics, and channel migration to assess depth of cover requirements and inspection mandates for pipeline operators. The Administrator must review regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water with a width of at least 100 feet within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This includes evaluating river crossings during extraordinary events, Integrity Management Plans for flooding evaluations, requirements for installing crossings with horizontal directional drilling, and issuing emergency orders for unsafe conditions. The Administrator must review regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water with a width of at least 100 feet within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This involves collaborating with various agencies and entities to gather relevant data and expertise. A report on the findings of the review, along with any recommendations for changes in laws or regulations, must be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days. Regulations incorporating the review's findings must be prescribed within one year of the report's submittal. Regulations must be updated to include review findings and report recommendations. SEC. 4. INCREASED TRANSPARENCY. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will establish a database of pipeline water crossings in the United States, including details such as pipeline operator, design classification, depth of cover, installation date, inspection dates, anomalies, and operational status during high flows. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will establish a database of national and state statistics on pipeline safety, including inspection percentages, High Consequence Areas, and compliance rates. The Administrator will post information on hazardous liquid pipeline response plans, including compliance percentages, types of pipeline crossings, and other relevant statistics on a publicly available website within one year of the enactment of the Act. Pipeline operators are required to provide a status indication, comprehensive description, and detailed summary of their oil spill response plans, excluding certain sensitive information. The Administrator will prescribe regulations for consultation on these plans. Pipeline operators must consult with local first responders and emergency services operators when constructing oil spill response plans. They are also required to file approved plans with listed local responders and provide updates as needed. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will review leak detection performance standards for hazardous liquid pipeline facilities, including the size of leaks detected and alarm response time. Additionally, regulations on the use of emergency flow restricting devices will be reviewed within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will review onshore gas and hazardous liquid gathering lines not regulated by the Administration, including recommendations on pipeline safety laws, regulations, and exemptions. Additionally, there will be expanded local involvement in the national contingency plan response management structure. SEC. 9. TRIBAL CONSULTATION. The National Contingency Plan will involve local authorities more in response management, without diminishing the On-Scene Coordinator's role. SEC. 9. TRIBAL CONSULTATION. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will establish a protocol for consulting with Indian tribes to provide technical assistance for regulating pipelines on tribal land. Pipeline operators on tribal land must submit oil spill response plans to the Administration.
